(d) Galvanostatic discharge–charge cycling curves of the Zn-air battery at 1 mA cm−2. Wang, B. Lv). State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 China Graphical abstract The synergistic effect between BC3 and graphitic N in boron- and nitrogen-codoped porous graphene plays a dominant role for oxygen reduction reaction. Rational design and optimization of metal-free electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is crucial for fuel cells and metal-air batteries. However, identifying design principle that links the active sites and their synergistic effects is far from satisfactory, especially for B,N-codoped graphene. Herein, we provide four B,N-codoped porous graphenes with tunable contents of pyridinic N, graphitic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O. BC3 shows multiple-fold specific activity compared with graphitic N and pyridinic N, while C-B(N)O offers no positive contribution. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the synergistic effect between graphitic N and BC3 can effectively facilitate the reduction of O2. These pinpoint that graphitic N and BC3 are the main active sites among various nitrogen or/and boron doping configurations. The most active catalyst exhibits superior activity than the commercial Pt/C catalyst using the RDE method in alkaline media, and displays comparable power density to Pt/C catalyst in Zn-air battery. Keywords B, N-codoped porous graphene ORR Zn-air battery Specific activity DFT 1 Introduction The necessity of the low-carbon economy and sustainable development in modern society greatly encourage the progress of fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1]. Rational design of highly active and cost-effective electrocatalysts for cathodic oxygen reduction reaction stands at the central stage for making these devices commercially available, since the sluggish reaction kinetics and high overpotential of ORR significantly limit the practical energy density and energy conversion efficiency [2]. Platinum and its alloys have been widely investigated as active catalysts for ORR [3,4], and ORR-favored Pt(1 1 1) facets and/or defects with hollow or frame structure were designed to maximize the exposed active sites and minimize the usage [5], still its common usage in large scale is hindered by the prohibitive costs and scarcity of platinum. Recently, metal-free heteroatom-doped carbonaceous materials as the cathodic ORR catalysts have attracted tremendous attention, not only because they exhibit comparable ORR activity to commercial Pt/C catalyst and superior durability, but also they are cost-effective and derive from earth-abundant elements [6–8]. To rationally design and optimize these metal-free catalysts, a deeper understanding of the origin of their electrocatalytic activity for ORR is highly requested, and a fundamental issue lied in which doping configuration contributes to the catalysis should be endowed with more important significance. Nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) is the most extensively investigated metal-free catalysts towards ORR. The pyridinic and graphitic N are described as the potential active sites, and the contribution of former is generally more important [9,10]. Nitrogen atom featured higher electronegativity (χN = 3.04) than that of carbon (χC = 2.55) atom can provide with electron-withdrawing ability and thus create positive charges on adjacent carbon atoms [11]. The altered charge or spin distribution of the sp2 carbon plane is the catalytic nature of metal-free graphene-based catalysts for ORR, as they can facilitate the oxygen adsorption or/and subsequent OO bond breaking [12]. In this regard, a higher degree of electron delocalization and polarization occurs in case of both electron-withdrawing and -donating atoms in graphene frameworks, thus several attempts have been made to improve the ORR catalytic activity by doping graphene with both electronegative N and electropositive B (χB = 2.05) atoms [7,8,13,14]. Unfortunately, the B,N co-doped graphene, based on previous reports, demonstrated diverse ORR performances. Several exhibited much more enhanced ORR activity than nitrogen-doped graphene and were even superior to commercial Pt/C, but others were much worse [8,13]. The differences of co-doped catalysts are mainly ascribed to the boron or/and nitrogen doping configurations. The isolated B and N configurations (especially, pyridinic N, graphitic N and BC3) rather than bonded B-N are of great importance to the ORR catalytic activity, because the neutralization between the extra electron of nitrogen atom and the vacant orbital of boron atom in the bonded B-N leads to unfavorable chemisorption of O2 [15–18]. Interestingly, Gong and coworkers suggested that the BN pair in the basal plane was inert to ORR, but the BN pair at the edges could polarize the neighboring C atoms and shown enhanced ORR properties via bridge adsorption of O2 [7]. However, C-B(N)O species, which is frequently identified in B,N-codoped graphenes by XPS measurements [19,20], is most likely to have B-N pair located at the edges and its effect on ORR activity remains unclear. To develop high-performance B, N-codoped catalysts, high concentration of the main active sites and their full exposure are required. However, the contribution of aforementioned configurations (pyridinic N, graphitic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O) and their possible synergy to catalytic performance for ORR, which are the cornerstone of exploring the active sites, have yet to be fully understood because of the relatively complicated boron or/and nitrogen configurations [21]. To address these issues, the preparation of co-doped catalysts with precisely controlled doping configuration and concentration in the atomic scale is highly desired. The catalysts should possess similar morphology, number of exposed edges and graphitization degree, as these properties would affect the ORR performance. B,N-codoped graphenes are supposed to have abundant pores, which could not only fully expose the active B,N configurations, but also facilitate ion transport and provide sufficient contact area between the catalysts, oxygen and electrolyte. Herein, we developed four B, N-codoped porous graphenes and controlled their B, N configurations and contents by altering the amount of surface oxygen-containing groups on N-doped porous graphene matrix and annealing time with boric acid. The contribution of four potentially active B or/and N configurations (namely graphitic N, pyridinic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O) was identified through the relationship between their relative contents and the ORR activity of four catalysts according to Guo et al.’s method [10]. Then the in-depth investigation on the DFT calculations disclosed the synergistic effect of graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3 on the adsorption and reduction of O2. The most active catalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic ORR performance comparable to commercial Pt/C both in the RDE measurement and in the Zn-air battery. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation Nitrogen-doped porous graphene (N-PG) was chosen as the matrix [22], as porous structure could provide sufficient access to the diverse doping configurations and doping of N-doped graphene with B atoms make it easier to get controlled doping configuration and concentration. The synthetic details of N-PG were presented in the Supplementary material. B,N-PG catalysts were synthesized by directly annealing N-PG with boric acid. Briefly, N-PG was loaded in a graphite boat and placed into the center of a quartz tube. Solid boric acid was placed in a lower temperature zone as the boron source. After exhausting the oxygen by argon gas, the quartz tube was put into the furnace when its temperature was increased to 500 °C, and then heated to 1000 °C for 15 min or 60 min to give B,N-PG-15 or B,N-PG-60, respectively. B,N-PG-O catalysts were synthesized by using HNO3-oxidized N-PG (named N-PG-O) as the matrix. Typically, N-PG (25 mg) was dispersed homogeneously in 8 M HNO3 (50 ml) by sonicating. The suspension was sealed in a Telfon-lined autoclave and maintained at 60 °C for 12 h. The obtained sample was filtrated and washed with deionized water and ethanol in turn for three times. After drying at 60 °C, N-PG-O was obtained. The doping process was all the same with B,N-PG. B,N-PG-O-15 and B,N-PG-O-60 was obtained by annealing N-PG-O with boric acid at 1000 °C for 15 or 60 min, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations JSM-7001F field emission scanning electron microscope was performed to obtain the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images. JEOL-2100F transmission electron microscope was performed to obtain the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images. Bruker D8-Advance-A25 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation was used to record X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. Labram HR800 Raman spectrometer equipped with a 514 nm Ar+ laser (Horiba Jobin-Yvon) was performed to obtain the Raman spectra. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos AXIS UL TRA DLD) was used to analyze the elemental composition and surface chemical configuration of synthesized catalysts. Micromeritcs Tristar 3020 with N2 as absorbate at 77 K was used to obtain the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, and the specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett-Teller (BET) method. 2.3 RDE-RRDE electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were carried out using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760D, CH Instruments, Inc., Shanghai, China) with a three-electrode cell. For ORR experiments, rotating disk electrode or rotating ring-disk electrode (RDE and RRDE, Pine Instruments Co. Ltd. USA) was loaded with catalysts and used as the working electrode. The reference and counter electrodes were an Hg/HgO (KOH, 1 M) electrode and a graphite rod, respectively. All the potentials in this work was converted to the reference of the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to E ( RHE ) = E ( Hg / HgO ) + E ( Hg / HgO ) Θ + 0.059 pH . Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed in O2 or N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at a scanning rate of 50 mV s−1. RDE and RRDE voltammetry were carried out in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH or 0.5 M H2SO4 solution at a scanning rate of 10 mV s−1 with various rotation rates (400–2025 rpm). Long-term stability tests of B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C (20%) catalysts were measured at a constant voltage of −0.1 V vs. Hg/HgO in O2 bubbled 0.1 M KOH electrolytes at a rotation rate of 1000 rpm. More details including the working electrode preparation and equations for electron transfer number and H2O2 yield were shown in the Supplementary material. 2.4 Zn-air battery measurements The cathode slurry was prepared by uniformly mixing of the electrocatalyst (N-PG, B,N-PG-O-15 or commercial Pt/C) and 10% Polyvinylidene Fluoride (PVDF) binder in the solvent of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The cathode slurry was pasted on carbon paper and then dried in a vacuum oven. The catalyst mass loading was about 1 mg cm−2. For the assembled Zn–air cell, the anode was a polished Zn plate, the electrolyte was 6 M KOH aqueous solution, and the separator was glass yarn. The CHI660E electrochemical working station was used to obtain the polarization curves. The LAND testing system was used to measure the galvanostatic discharge and charge cycling (10 min discharge and 10 min charge with a current density of 1 mA cm−2). All these measurements were performed under ambient air conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Precisely controlled doping configuration As depicted in Fig. 1 a, B,N-PG and B,N-PG-O were synthesized by annealing N-PG or N-PG-O with boric acid. After annealing at two different time (15 and 60 min), four catalysts with varied B,N doping configurations and concentration were obtained. XPS measurements were performed to determine the B and N doping configurations of as-synthesized catalysts. The full scan surveys all indicate the existence of C, N, B and O elements (Fig. S3), and the detailed contents are summarized in Table 1 and Table S1. As shown in Fig. 1b, the high-resolution N 1s spectra are deconvoluted into five different components with binding energies of 402.8 ± 0.2, 401.4 ± 0.1, 400.0 ± 0.1, 398.9 ± 0.1 and 397.9 ± 0.1, attributed to oxidized N, graphitic N, pyrrolic N, pyridinic N and B-N bond, respectively [19,23,24]. The high-resolution B1s spectra shown in Fig. 1c are deconvolved into four peaks corresponding to BCO2 (192.4 ± 0.1 eV), C-B(N)O (191.4 ± 0.1 eV), h-BN/BC2O (190.5 ± 0.1 eV) and BC3 (189.2 ± 0.1 eV) [19,21,25]. BCO2 and BC2O are largely derived from borinic and boronic. C-B(N)O is boron atom surrounded by carbon, nitrogen and oxygen atoms and exists in all of the four samples, which is most likely to have B-N pairs at the edges. It should be noted that BC3 group, namely the substitutional boron in graphene frameworks, is only observed in B,N-PG-O-15 and B,N-PG-O-60. During the doping process, oxygen-containing groups grafted on N-PG-O are easily removed at high temperatures, which simultaneously generates some active sites that are easily bonded with boron active radicals [26], consequently resulting in the formation of BC3 in the B,N-PG-O samples. On the contrary, boron active radicals are preferred to bond with nitrogen atoms of N-PG matrix in the boron doping process, because the bond energy of B–N (εB–N) is much larger than that of C-N (εC-N) and C-B (εC-B), and B–N domains in the graphene matrix are thermodynamically favored [27]. As shown in Table 1, prolonging doping time led to increased B contents in the final samples. All samples contain plenty of oxygen, which are mainly derived from the boron doping species and the physicochemically adsorbed oxygen-containing components, presumably O2, CO2 and H2O [28,29]. To identify the contribution of doping configurations towards ORR, the morphology and structure of as-synthesized catalysts should be nearly identical. The morphology and microstructure of B, N-codoped porous graphene catalysts were analyzed by SEM and TEM. Here, B,N-PG-O-15 was taken as an example firstly. The typical SEM image shows the crumpled and micrometer-scaled sheets morphology with honeycomb-like structure (Fig. 2 a). The enlarged view (Fig. 2a, inset) reveals rippled and transparent nanosheets entangled with each other and consequently assembled into the micrometer-scaled sheets. Further details of the morphology were illustrated by TEM image (Fig. 2b), which confirms the three-dimensional honeycomb character constructed by cross-linked graphene walls. The HRTEM image (Fig. 2b, inset) shows the few-layer nature of the B,N-PG-O-15 catalyst (1–10 layers) with a graphitic (0 0 2) plane spacing of ∼0.35 nm, and the interpenetrated holes with an average diameter of ∼10 nm randomly dispersed in the basal plane. When we compare four codoped catalysts in Figs. 2 and S4, there are no obvious differences in morphology and porous structure. Furthermore, N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were performed to evaluate specific surface areas and the textural properties. The specific surface area of B,N-PG-15 and B,N-PG-60 were 1280 m2 g−1 and 985 m2 g−1, respectively. After introducing boron atoms into N-PG-O, the specific surface area was slightly increased to 1303 m2 g−1 for B,N-PG-O-15 and 1317 m2 g−1 for B,N-PG-O-60. As depicted in Fig. 2c, all synthesized catalysts present type-IV isotherm characteristic. The capillary condensation steps reveal conspicuous mesoporous structure and large mesopore volume, and the up-going portions at the high relative pressure (P/P0 ≥ 0.95) evidence the existence of macropores. As shown in Fig. 2d, the corresponding pore size distribution (PSD) plots reflect that all as-synthesized catalysts possess similar hierarchical porous texture, and exhibit two clear peaks centered at ∼3.5 nm and ∼8 nm. The small one is generated by the etching reaction between the amorphous region of N-PG/N-PG-O and the water steam released by boric acid, while the large one is the basic characteristic of N-PG matrix. The porous structure is of great significance for exploring the active sites because it can effectively inhibit sheet agglomeration and provide sufficient contact between the catalysts, oxygen and electrolyte in ORR process. XRD and Raman spectroscopy were further used to explore the structure of the as-synthesized metal-free catalysts. As shown in Fig. S5a, XRD patterns of all catalysts exhibit broad diffraction peaks at ca. 25°, which are indexed to the (0 0 2) diffraction of graphene sheets with the d-spacing of 3.5 Å. Fig. S5b shows the Raman spectra of four catalysts. The two peaks at 1350 and 1595 cm−1 correspond to the well-defined D band and G band in graphene, respectively. D band is ascribed to structural defects or edges and disordered structures of graphene, while G band derives from the doubly degenerate phonon mode of sp2 carbon frameworks [30]. The intensity ratio of D band to G band (ID/IG) is traditionally related to the density of defects [31]. The ID/IG ratios of B,N-PG-O-15 and B,N-PG-O-60 are 1.05 and 1.10, respectively, while that of B,N-PG-15 and B,N-PG-60 are slightly higher to 1.11 and 1.16, respectively. The slight difference of ID/IG would be attributed to the amounts of dopants and different doping configurations because the E2g mode from h-BN (∼1360 cm−1) would influence the intensity of D band in graphene [32]. 3.2 Electrochemical performance for ORR Cyclic voltammetry was firstly carried out to evaluate the electrocatalytic ORR activities of B,N-PG-15, B,N-PG-60, B,N-PG-O-15, B,N-PG-O-60 and Pt/C (20 wt%). Fig. 3 a depicts that despite only double-layer charging current shown in N2-saturated electrolyte, B,N-PG-O-15 exhibited a conspicuous reduction peak at +0.80 V (vs. RHE) when the electrolyte was saturated with O2. This value was more positive than those of B,N-PG-O-60 (0.78 V vs. RHE), B,N-PG-15 (0.74 V vs. RHE) and B,N-PG-60 (0.74 V vs. RHE). These B,N-codoped catalysts exhibited much more positive peak potentials than N-PG (0.72 V vs. RHE), which suggests that introducing B atoms into N-doped graphene matrix can effectively facilitate the electrocatalytic activity for ORR. Meanwhile, the peak potential of B,N-PG-O-15 is similar to that of Pt/C (20 wt%) (0.81 V), highlighting the excellent electrocatalytic ORR activity of B,N-PG-O-15. Fig. 3b depicts linear polarization curves of different catalysts to achieve a better comparison. The onset potential (E0) and half-wave potential (E1/2) of N-PG were 0.86 V and 0.74 V vs. RHE, respectively. After doping N-PG-O by using boric acid in a proper time, the onset potential and half-wave potential of B,N-PG-O-15 were dramatically improved to 0.99 V and 0.86 V vs. RHE, respectively. Its onset potential is ∼0.03, 0.05 and 0.06 V more positive than those of B,N-PG-O-60, B,N-PG-15 and B,N-PG-60, respectively, and its half-wave potential is ∼0.03, 0.04 and 0.06 V more positive than those of B,N-PG-O-60, B,N-PG-15 and B,N-PG-60, respectively. Fig. 3c shows that the limiting current density of B,N-PG-O-15 is positively related to the electrode rotation speed. Fig. 3d shows the electron-transfer number and H2O2 yield of various catalysts. B,N-PG-O-15 has the highest electron-transfer number (n = 3.84–3.95) and lowest H2O2 yield (H2O2% < 9) among as-synthesized catalysts, which is sufficiently close to that of commercial Pt/C (n = 3.87–3.92, H2O2% < 7). This result indicates that B,N-PG-O-15 is similar to Pt/C with a preference for the four-electron reduction pathway. Fig. 3e shows the Tafel plots of various catalysts derived from LSV curves in Fig. 3b. At 0.85 V, the kinetic current density of B,N-PG-O-15 is around 6.14 mA·cm−2, which is significantly higher than that of B,N-PG-O-60 (2.49 mA·cm−2), B,N-PG-15 (1.56 mA·cm−2), B,N-PG-60 (1.04 mA·cm−2) and N-PG (0.25 mA·cm−2) electrodes, and even surpasses the commercial Pt/C catalyst (2.95 mA·cm−2), signifying that B,N-PG-O-15 is an excellent ORR catalyst. Meanwhile, the Tafel slope of B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C was 59 and 67 mV/dec, respectively. The similar values indicate that B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C have an analogous reaction mechanism towards ORR, that is, their rate-determining step is ascribed to the first electron reduction of oxygen [33]. Based on these results, the overall electrocatalytic ORR performance exhibits an enhancement in the following order: N-PG < B,N-PG-60 < B,N-PG-15 < B,N-PG-O-60 < B,N-PG-O-15. More importantly, B,N-PG-O-15 exhibits a superior ORR activity compared to commercial Pt/C catalyst in alkaline solution, and more extraordinary performance than most of the previously reported boron and nitrogen-codoped carbonaceous electrocatalysts, as shown in Table S2. The tolerance toward methanol and long-term stability are the key evaluation factors for the cathode catalyst of fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Fig. 3f shows chronoamperometry curves of B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C (20 wt%) catalysts. B,N-PG-O-15 exhibited an excellent durability with a slow attenuation of about 5.4% in relative current after 10,000 s, while commercial Pt/C showed a loss of 19.6%. The inset shows that after adding 1 M methanol, the current density of Pt/C catalyst decreased dramatically, while that of B,N-PG-O-15 was nearly invariable. These results suggest that the B,N-PG-O-15 catalyst has a higher ORR durability and a greater tolerance to methanol crossover than the commercial Pt/C catalyst in an alkaline environment. Besides the alkaline electrolyte, there are a number of fuel cells using acid electrolyte. Therefore, electrocatalytic ORR properties are further explored in an O2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 via RDE and RRDE voltammetry. As shown in Fig. 4 , linear polarization curves of as-synthesized catalysts exhibit a positive shift in the following order: N-PG < B,N-PG-60 < B,N-PG-15 < B,N-PG-O-60 < B,N-PG-O-15, which is consistent with the results from the alkaline solution. The B,N-PG-O-15, which shows the best ORR activity among all these catalysts, behaves an onset potential of 0.82 V vs. RHE and a half-wave potential of 0.68 V vs. RHE. Although the onset and half-wave potentials of B,N-PG-O-15 were about both 110 mV negative to that of Pt/C (E0 = 0.93 V, E1/2 = 0.79 V), B,N-PG-O-15 has exhibited outstanding ORR performance among the reported metal-free catalysts in acidic electrolyte, as shown in Table S3. Additionally, as shown in Fig. S6, its electron-transfer number is 3.81–3.89 in the potential range of 0.1–0.7 V, indicating that the B,N-PG-O-15 also possesses remarkable ORR efficiency in acidic solution with an intrinsic four electron-transfer process. Noteworthy, the codoped catalysts in this study show greatly improved electrocatalytic ORR activity compared to solely nitrogen-doped porous graphene in both alkaline and acidic electrolyte. 3.3 Zn–air battery performance A home-built Zn-air battery was assembled to evaluate the practical application properties of B,N-PG-O-15, since test conditions of the practical Zn–air battery are very different from the preceding RDE measurements due to the higher electrolyte concentration and the air atmosphere [34]. Fig. 5 a shows the discharge polarization curves and power density curves of Zn–air batteries with the air cathode of N-PG, B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C. The maximum power density based on B,N-PG-O-15 was determined to be 30.43 mW cm−2, which is comparable to commercial Pt/C catalyst (32.36 mW cm−2). As shown in Fig. 5b, the open circuit voltage of the Zn–air cell remained at ∼1.39 and ∼1.41 V for the B,N-PG-O-15 and Pt/C, respectively. Fig. 5c displays galvanostatic discharge curves of the battery, and shows that the battery with the B,N-PG-O-15 cathode catalyst presented a slightly higher discharge voltage than that of Pt/C at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2. Fig. 5d exhibits the galvanostatic discharge-charge cycling curves of rechargeable Zn–air batteries with air-cathode of B,N-PG-O-15 or Pt/C. At the current density of 1 mA cm−2, B,N-PG-O-15 presented similar discharging and charging voltage to that of Pt/C during the first few cycles, but shortly afterwards shown an increasingly downward discharging voltage and simultaneously upward charging voltage. While in N-PG case, a similar charge-discharge behavior and an inferior Zn–air battery performance were observed in comparison with B,N-PG-O-15 (Fig. S7). Taken together, the B,N-PG-O-15 as the cathode catalyst in a practical Zn-air battery shows excellent activity which is nearly equal to commercial Pt/C, but it suffers from inferior cycling durability. Generally, when air is used as the combust, carbonate ions generated by the reaction of hydroxyl ions and CO2, not only precipitated inside the pores and holes of the catalyst that could block a part of active sites and effective surface area, but also accumulated in the liquid electrolyte, consequently resulting in the mitigation of ORR activity and stability in alkaline media [35]. 3.4 The calculations of specific activity Based on the aforementioned analysis, B,N-PG-15, B,N-PG-60, B,N-PG-O-60 and B,N-PG-O-15 display significantly different electrocatalytic activities for ORR in both alkaline and acid electrolyte. However, the as-synthesized catalysts show analogous morphology, porous structure and graphitization degree. Concurrently, Fig. S8. reveals that all catalysts exhibit similar semi-circular loops in the high-medium frequency region, which suggests that they possess similar electronic conductivity. Therefore, the obvious distinction of electrocatalytic ORR performance of these B, N codoped porous graphenes is primarily dependent upon the difference of their boron or/and nitrogen configurations. Generally, pyridinic N, graphitic N and BC3 groups are considered as the most active nitrogen and boron configurations in graphene for ORR [17,22], while h-BN domains are virtually ORR inactive because their steep uphill process for binding of O2 and big barriers for proton transfer to adsorbed O [7]. According to DFT calculations, B-N pair located at edges plays a positive role in enhancing the ORR performance. C-B(N)O group provides a great probability of having B-N pair being at the edge and is frequently identified in B,N-codoped carbon materials, but its effect on ORR has not been explored comprehensively. Calculating specific activities of pyridinic N, graphitic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O is a powerful strategy to understanding their contributions towards ORR. Recently, Guo et al. proposed a method to calculate the specific activity per pyridinic N in N-doped graphene powder catalysts. The specific activity per pyridinic N is transferred electron numbers in ORR per second on one pyridinic N site at the catalyst surface. Transferred electron numbers per second were determined by the current density of the catalyst at a proper potential in the linear polarization curve, at which the current density is not so small and the oxygen diffusion effect is not so pronounced [10]. Hence, based on Guo et al.’s method, the relative contents of these four configurations and the specific activity per area of the four catalysts were used to establish four equations, which are expressed as follows: Activity per area = ∑ ( ρ i X i ) × D atom atoms cm 2 = J ORR A cm 2 × N e per coulomb per second e - A · s W catalyst g cm 2 × S BET cm 2 g In this equation, J ORR is the current density at various potential from LSV curves in Figs. 3b and 4, N e is a constant of electron numbers in 1 C (6.24 × 1018 e− A−1 s−1), D atom is the carbon atomic density in one layer of graphene sheet (3.82 × 1015 atoms cm−2), W catalyst is the mass loading of the catalyst in RDE, S BET is the specific surface area of the catalyst evaluated by BET method, ρ i is the atomic percentage of pyridinic N, graphitic N, C-B(N)O and BC3 species in the catalyst, and X i is the corresponding specific activity for ORR, respectively [10]. Fig. 6 shows the specific activity of graphitic N, pyridinic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O species in the potential range of 0.85–0.90 V and 0.64–0.69 V vs. RHE for alkaline and acid electrolyte, respectively, and suggests that their contribution increases in the following order in both alkaline and acid electrolyte in this study: C-B(N)O < pyridinic N < graphitic N < BC3. It is reasonable to conclude that BC3 plays the most important role among these four species, graphitic N also contributes to the ORR activity because of its positive specific activity, C-B(N)O species has negative specific activity and plays no part in ORR, but the role of pyridinic N is indecisive because it shows a slightly higher specific activity over graphitic N in a narrow range which near the on-set potential. As the applied potential decreases, the specific activity of graphitic N gradually increases, while that of pyridinic N decreases below zero. Interestingly, previously reported B-doped carbonaceous materials that contain BC3 group display modest catalytic activity [20,36], and pyridinic N has been generally considered as the dominant active site in nitrogen-doped carbonaceous electrocatalysts for ORR [9,10]. Combined with the boosted activity with BC3 species and the transition of active N doping configuration from “pyridinic N” to “graphitic N” after B incorporation in this work, the synergistic effect between graphitic N, pyridinic N and BC3 species should be further investigated. 3.5 DFT calculations To gain insight into the synergistic coupling effect between graphitic N, pyridinic N and BC3, and the effect of C-B(N)O towards ORR, the adsorption of O2 on the surface of different B, N-codoped graphenes was firstly examined by density functional theory (DFT) calculations with Gaussian 09 (Revision D.01; Gaussian, Inc.,Wallingford, CT, 2010) [37]. The details of the calculations were described in the Supplementary material. Previously, Zheng et al. suggested that a N atom meta to a B atom is more beneficial to adsorb and bond with HO2 than ortho and para to a B atom, because in the B-C-N heterostructure, the N atom would polarize adjacent C atom and then the C atom donates extra electrons to the 2p orbital of adjacent B atom, consequently resulting in “activated” B site. Moreover, the increase of the distance between B and N dopants gradually decreases the strength of the synergistic effect [13]. Therefore, a pyridinic N or a graphitic N atom meta to a B atom was chosen as the model. As the basal plane, armchair edges and zigzag edges of graphene have different electronic structures [38,39], we constructed three possible structures for graphitic N-BC3, two structures for pyridinic N-BC3, and two structures for C-B(N)O. As shown in Fig. 7 , the interacted structures of 3O2 with graphitic N-BC3, pyridinic N-BC3, and C-B(N)O species were constructed, which were fully optimized at the M06-2X/6-31G(d) level of theory with all atoms fully relaxed [40,41]. The shortest distances between O2 and B,N-codoped graphenes are 2.95, 2.91 and 3.11 Å for graphitic N-BC3, pyridinic N-BC3 and C-B(N)O, respectively. These distances indicate that the absorption of O2 on the surface of three different nano-electrodes should belong to physisorption. The binding energies between 3O2 and B,N-codoped graphene catalysts were obtained at the M06-2X/6-311 + G(d)//M06-2X/6-31G(d) level of theory. The corresponding binding energy for graphitic N-BC3 is 0.54 eV, which is close to previous studies of O2 adsorption on Pt, ranging among 0.43–0.62 eV on Pt(1 1 1) [42–44] and 0.53–0.83 eV on Ptn clusters (n = 2–5) [45]; while binding energies for pyridinic N-BC3 and C-B(N)O are 0.19 and −0.88 eV, respectively. These results further confirm that the three cases are the weak physisorption. It is clear that the absorption of O2 on the surface of C-B(N)O was energy-unfavorable. In addition, the high binding energy may reflect that graphitic N-BC3 has a high activity for the 3O2 reduction and the negative binding energy indicates that C-B(N)O cannot absorb 3O2 and has a low activity, which is consistent with our experimental result. The activity of graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3 for ORR is further elucidated by calculating the binding free energies of all intermediates involved in the reaction. The Eley-Rideal mechanism is widely used in electrochemical reduction of O2 [44,46], and the overall reactions can be written as: (1) O 2 + ∗ → ∗ O 2 (2) ∗ O 2 + H + + e - → ∗ OOH (3) ∗ OOH + H + + e - → ∗ O + H 2 O (4) ∗ O + H + + e - + H 2 O → ∗ OH + H 2 O (5) ∗ OH + H + + e - + H 2 O → ∗ + 2 H 2 O where ∗ refers to the adsorption site in the specific B,N-codoped graphene model in this work. The optimized configurations of all possible intermediates on the surfaces of graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3 are displayed in Fig. S9, and their binding energies are obtained at the M06-2X/6-311 + G(d)//M06-2X/6-31G(d) level of theory and listed in Table 2 . The binding energies of OOH, O-H2O and OH-H2O on graphitic N-BC3 are 2.60, 5.22 and 3.76 eV, respectively, indicating that the three intermediates are chemically adsorbed on the surface of graphitic N-BC3. The similar result can be found for the complete O2 reduction by the pyridinic N-BC3 species. In addition, the calculated free energy profiles were also obtained at the M06-2X/6-31G(d) level of theory based on Nørskov et al.’s works [47–49]. As shown in Fig. S10, it is clear that the free energy of the intermediate species at every elementary step is downward at U = 0 V, confirming the applicability of graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3 in ORR [46,50]. As shown in Fig. 8 , if the applied electrode potential was shifted to the equilibrium potential of U0 = 1.23 V, the first and fourth electron/proton-transfer steps become uphill, and thus a potential bias (η = U0 − Uon-set) is generally required to initial the reaction [51]. The highest energy barrier is observed at the first electron transfer step, which is 0.87 and 0.82 eV for graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3, respectively. These values fall in the calculated value range of metal-free heteroatom-doped carbonaceous materials (0.7–1.02 eV) in the literature [51–53]. The theoretically predicted onset potential range based on Jiao et al.’s model is 0.58–0.79 V and 0.63–0.84 V for graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3, respectively. Our experiment results (0.75–0.82 V) is in the range but around the upper limit. It is worth noting that abundant pores, edges and defects (bending and distortion) in real catalysts are commonly overlooked in calculation models, which could also benefit improving the onset potential [12,39,54]. The 0.05 eV lower energy barrier of pyridinic N-BC3 might be the reason for the slightly higher specific activity of pyridinic N than that of graphitic N around the onset potential in Fig. 6. In addition, the fourth reduction step of OH∗–H2O to 2H2O has an energy barrier of 0.12 and 0.29 eV for graphitic N-BC3 and pyridinic N-BC3, respectively, which is in line with previous reports of heteroatom-doped graphene [46]. The lower overall reaction free energy change at the equilibrium potential (U0 = 1.23 V) implies more favorable ORR performance in the theoretical viewpoint [48]. As a result, the graphitic N-BC3 with lower overall reaction free energy change is more favorable, in agreement with the experimental result that the graphitic N shows a better specific activity over pyridinic N-BC3 at a wide potential range in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution. Therefore, the synergistic effect between BC3 and graphitic-N are more pronounced over pyridinic N-BC3 species. 4 Conclusions In summary, B, N-codoped porous graphenes with diverse B,N configurations and contents were readily obtained via annealing N-PG or N-PG-O with boric acid in different time periods. Together with the experiment and DFT investigations, we demonstrated that graphitic N and BC3 are the main active sites among various B or/and N configurations, and their synergistic effect can effectively facilitate the physisorption and reduction of O2. The B,N-PG-O-15, which was the most active catalyst among the series, not only exhibited superior ORR performance than the commercial Pt/C (20%) catalyst in alkaline electrolyte, but also could compete with it in acidic electrolytes. The Zn–air battery with air cathode of B,N-PG-O-15 displayed comparable performance to the cathode of commercial Pt/C. This combined experimental and computational study sheds light on the origin of ORR electrocatalysis for B,N codoped graphene, and paves the way to rationally design of highly efficient ORR electrocatalysts for metal-air batteries. coredata.dc:description: Rational design and optimization of metal-free electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is crucial for fuel cells and metal-air batteries. However, identifying design principle that links the active sites and their synergistic effects is far from satisfactory, especially for B,N-codoped graphene. Herein, we provide four B,N-codoped porous graphenes with tunable contents of pyridinic N, graphitic N, BC3 and C-B(N)O. BC3 shows multiple-fold specific activity compared with graphitic N and pyridinic N, while C-B(N)O offers no positive contribution. Density functional theory calculations indicate that the synergistic effect between graphitic N and BC3 can effectively facilitate the reduction of O2. These pinpoint that graphitic N and BC3 are the main active sites among various nitrogen or/and boron doping configurations. The most active catalyst exhibits superior activity than the commercial Pt/C catalyst using the RDE method in alkaline media, and displays comparable power density to Pt/C catalyst in Zn-air battery.
coredata.dc:title: Synergistic enhancement of oxygen reduction reaction with BC3 and graphitic-N in boron- and nitrogen-codoped porous graphene
